Department of Chemistry Indian Institute of Technology (IIT-BHU) Varanasi India The current work demonstrates a simple solid-state method for producing barium silicate catalyst for transesterification of Anabaena oil. The designed Ba2SiO4 spinel catalyst was characterised by following techniques such as thermo gravimetric analysis (TGA-DSC), powder X ray diffraction (P-XRD), furrier transfer infrared spectroscopy (FT-IR), scanning electron microscopy and electron diffraction spectroscopy (SEM-EDX), BET-surface area analyser and Hammett indictor acid-base titration method. The optimum condition for achieving highest FAME conversion of 98.4 % was observed at 65 °C, 12:1 methanol to oil molar ratio at 4h of reaction time. The catalyst was also stable up to six cycles with 98.1 % FAME conversion. Fuel properties of synthesized biodiesel were also compared with the ASTM standard. Kinetics studies revealed that transesterification of Anabaena oil is compactable with pseudo first order model with comparable activation energy 36.48 kJ/mol. The reaction equilibrium constants were also studied in the temperature range of 45°–65 °C and the standard thermodynamic properties like ΔH# = 98.73 kJ mol−1, ΔG# = 23.53 kJ mol−1, ΔS# = 0.864 kJ mol−1 were obtained at 65 °C. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords Barium silicate Transesterification Anabaena oil Methanol Activation energy Fatty acid methyl ester (FAME) Data availability Data will be made available on request. Introduction The gradual increase in the consumption rate of fossil fuels and their depletion are the big concern for the world today. Besides this, the emission of greenhouse gases has also become serious problem to the environment and human health. As a result, researchers have made good effort in search of alternative source of energy [1–3]. Biodiesel is considered as a sustainable clean renewable energy resource due to its biodegradability, nontoxicity, and environment friendly nature. Biodiesel is a prominent alternative fuel which can be used in place of diesel fuels. Biodiesel is a high oxygen content and sulphur free fuel, so it produces less emission of hazardous gases as compared to diesel fuel. Even with many advantages biodiesel causes debate between cleaner emission and its high production cost. Almost 70–95 % of total biodiesel production cost is based on feedstock selection [4–6]. The application of microalgae as feedstock is better choice as compared to edible and non-edible oil plant because of its high growth rate, photosynthesis, and oil productivity [7]. Microalgae have ability to grow in fresh water, marine water, land, brackish etc. It does not require special arable land for cultivation like edible as well as nonedible plants. In addition, microalgae also reduce global warming increasing factor CO2 by consuming 1.8 g of CO2 to produce 1 g of dry biomass [8–9]. Among various microalgal species Spirullina platensis is used as a potential feedstock in biodiesel production because of having many properties like high lipid content, easy cultivation and short life span [10–12]. It can be used as source of other biochemical composition like protein, carbohydrate, chlorophyll etc after lipid extraction [13]. Biodiesel is a long chain fatty acid methyl ester produced from alcoholysis of triglycerides in presence of relevant catalyst. Biodiesel is considered as an environmental benign fuel as it is prepared from renewable feedstocks, it is non-toxic, biodegradable and eco-friendly in nature. Commonly, sulphuric acid and sodium hydroxide have been used as homogenous catalyst and provided very good yield of biodiesel due to their high efficiency at moderate temperature and pressure. Many researchers used sulphuric acid as catalyst and obtained FAME conversion (90–95 %) from various species of microalgae at 30 °C in 4 h reaction time [10–11] while Li et al. used immobilized lipase as catalyst and reported FAME conversion of 93 % from the same feedstock in 12 h [14]. Based on literature survey, some studies are reported on biodiesel production from microalgae using heterogeneous catalyst [15–16]. Carrero et al. [17] reported highest biodiesel yield from N. gaditana microalgae using ZSM-5, H-Beta zeolite, and H-ZSM-5 zeolites at 115 °C in 4 h. Umdu et al. [18] used alumina supported calcium and magnesium oxide catalyst for transesterification of N. oculata at 50 °C. Other researchers also studied on same feedstock (N. oculata) and they achieved 92 % yield by using alumina-calcium oxide catalyst at 60 °C [19]. Heterogeneous catalysis is preferred to homogeneous and enzyme catalysis for the production of biodiesel. The use of heterogeneous catalysis in the trans-esterification process has various benefits, including simple catalyst regeneration and reuse as well as easy conductivity due to its less corrosive nature. In comparison to acid heterogeneous catalyst, base heterogeneous catalyst is more suitable for transesterification reactions because faster reaction and more effective at low temperatures [17].Thus, it reduces the total production cost and helps to make the biodiesel economically sustainable fuel. In base heterogeneous catalyst, their basic site which exist on the surface take part in the transesterification reaction. [18] Several studies in catalyst synthesis have been reported on support material such as zeolites, hydrotalcites, alumina, zirconia, silica, and other metal oxide for biodiesel synthesis [19]. In recent year, zeolites have drawn more attention in catalyst preparation due to its high surface area, specific pore volume and great stability [18]. But being microporous in nature, mass transfer limitation is the main disadvantage. Along with its high cost make it unprofitable for biodiesel production. Large-scale biodiesel production requires catalysts that are more efficient, less expensive, easy to build, and eco-friendly. Silica appears to be one of the most appropriate materials employed as a support in catalyst synthesis for the manufacture of biodiesel by reaching the criteria. Several silica-based catalysts have been studied in biodiesel synthesis [16,20–22]. Silica is inactive for transesterification reaction, but it can take little role in reaction at high temperature for long duration. But silica is good supporting material to prepare some heterogeneous catalyst because of its mesoporous nature, large surface area and high thermal stability. Its unique pore structure offers more surfaces for incorporation of active species and reduces mass transfer limitation [23–24]. Roschat et al. synthesised Na2SiO3 heterogeneous catalyst and reported 94 % FAME yield at 2.5 wt.% catalyst loading [25]. Dai et al. have studied on Li2SiO4 catalyst and reported 76.2 % conversion with 3 wt.% catalyst loading [16]. Nonetheless, to the best of our information, the barium incorporated silica material has not been reported yet in transesterification reaction for biodiesel production. Some have selected barium silicate (Ba2SiO4) as catalyst, due to synergetic effect of silica and barium basicity performs as basic catalyst. Barium silicates are widely use in white light emitting diodes, compact fluorescent lamps, development of luminescent appliance, especially in scintillators etc. Barium silicates have significant properties like structural variety, similar melting point, high thermal and chemical stability [26]. Most common routes reported for synthesis of barium silicate were precipitation method, in which inorganic salt like Ba (NO3)2, BaCl2 or organic barium salt like Ba(CH3COO)2 precipitated with silica existing reagent such as sodium silicate, silica gel or tetraethoxysilane. Then precipitate solid intermediate is calcined at range of 900°–1100 °C. There are some other techniques have been reported for synthesis of alkaline metal silicate such as sol-gel, co-precipitation, and impregnation method. These synthesis methods require expensive raw material along with several processing step. Therefore, these methods are costly and require longer time which makes them inapt for commercial purpose. Solid state method is the best technique for synthesis of cheap catalyst because it takes shorter time and reduces processing step during catalyst preparation. Therefore, in present work, this method was applied for synthesis of catalyst and it is used for environmental benign biodiesel production from green and renewable feedstock Alagal oil. The catalyst is recyclable and used for several cycles of biodiesel synthesis with high atom economy. Glycerol produced as a by-product is used for synthesis of Glycerol carbonate in our laboratory which is a value added product for other industry [27]. So the above synthesis process is satisfying zero waste technology and can be considered as green process. The present study explores the synthesis of Barium silicate (Ba2SiO4) and its application for conversion of Anabaena oil into biodiesel first time. Anabaena cultivated in closed photo bioreactor was chosen as the microalga feedstock and oil extracted from Anabaena was characterized. The solid-state approach was used to create the barium silicate catalyst, and several methodologies were used to evaluate it. Reusability of Ba2SiO4 in transesterification reaction was also assessed. Besides that, the fuel characteristics of the obtained biodiesel product was examined and matched with standard fuel specification. Material Silica (SiO2), Barium nitrate (BaNO3)2, methanol (CH3OH), anhydrous sodium sulphate and acetone (CH3COCH3) of analytical grade were procured from Merck, Mumbai, India. Anabaena PCC 7120 culture was obtained from the Botany Department at Banaras Hindu University in India, and spectroscopic analysis was used to track the microalgae's development. The culture was maintained in a vertically aligned photo bioreactor using BG11 medium with a pH of 7. Anabaena cultivation for biomass production and oil extraction was already explained in our previous article published by our research group [28] Catalyst preparation Barium silicate (Ba2SiO4) catalyst was synthesized by solid state reaction method. Silica (SiO2) and barium nitrate Ba (NO3)2 were mixed in their stoichiometric ratio of 2:1. The mixing procedure was performed for 1 h by mixing of acetone in ball mill instrument. After that, calcination of the mixture was carried out at 900 °C for 4 h. Then the resultant was powdered into fine particle by mortar pestle and stored in desiccator for further characterization and application in biodiesel production. Catalyst characterization Many techniques have been used to investigate the physico-chemical characteristics of synthesized catalyst. TGA/DSC study was carried out by heating the sample in air atmosphere from 50 to 1000 °C at a rate of 10°/min on Perkin Elmer Pyris-1 instrument. The calcined material underwent a powder X-ray diffraction (XRD) analysis on a Bruker D8 diffractometer outfitted with Cu-K radiation. With a 0.02 step function and a 2-angle range between 10° and 80°, the diffraction pattern was recorded at a 5°min scan rate. The Eco-ATR device recorded the catalyst's Fourier transform infrared (FT-IR) spectra in the 400–4000 cm−1 range using a Ze-Se ATR crystal and a 24-scan time with a 4 cm−1 resolution. The morphology and elemental compositions of the designed catalysts were determined using energy dispersive X-ray spectroscopy (EDX) and high-resolution scanning electron microscopy (HR-SEM). Transesterification The catalyst, Ba2SiO4 prepared from silica and barium nitrate by solid state method was used for transesterification of Anabaena oil to prepare biodiesel. The effect of each reaction parameter (catalyst concentration, stirring speed, temperature & methanol: oil ratio) on biodiesel yield was studied. The reaction mixture was removed once the transesterification reaction was finished and poured out in separating funnel to separate the glycerol as by-product, further washed with water followed by rotavapour to remove unreacted methanol. The catalyst was extracted out of the reaction-mixture washed with acetone and re-used. The physico-chemical properties of biodiesel were determined as per standard procedure. Result and discussion Thermal analysis The thermal decomposition behaviour of uncalcined barium silicate has been shown in Fig. 1 . Thermal analysis was performed from 50 °C to 1000 °C with heating rate 10 °C per min and the total 50.02 % weight loss has been observed in thermo gravimetric curve. In TGA curve, two weight losses have been observed. The first weight loss 5.48 % began from 50 °C and completed up to 565 °C due to removal of atmospheric and crystalline water [29,30]. While, the second weight loss 34.54 %, began from 565 °C and completed at 900 °C due to removal of NO2 gas and O2 gas. After 900 °C no more weight loss was seen, so it implies to perform the calcination at 900 °C. The three endothermic peaks were observed in DSC curve. The first peak obtained at 470 °C due to expel of crystalline water. The second peak observed at 602 °C is ascribed to the melting of Ba(NO3)2, however the third peak appeared at 670 °C because of degradation of barium nitrate into barium oxide. The obtained result is also comparable to our previous published result of synthesis of Ba2TiO4 by solid state method in which the peak at 625 °C is due to melting of Ba(NO3)2 and another peak at 690 °C is due to degradation of Ba(NO3)2 to BaO. Then BaO reacts with TiO2 to form BaTiO4. [28]. The same mechanism is also applied here, after decomposition of Ba(NO3)2 to BaO, it reacts with SiO2, which approves the formation of Ba2SiO4 by the reaction of solid SiO2 and melted Ba (NO3)2 phase, given in following equation. (1) 2Ba (NO3)2 + SiO2 → Ba2SiO4+ 4NO2 + O2 X-ray diffraction analysis XRD analysis was carried out to determine the crystal structure, phase, and crystalline size of the produced catalyst. The XRD pattern of Ba2SiO4 has been demonstrated in Fig. 2 . The strong characteristics peaks at 2θ = 18.27, 21.08, 23.28, 29. 72, 31.04, 38.52, 41.79, 43.37, 51.93, 54.32 and 67.05 corresponds to (100), (110), (111), (210), (121), (101), (201), (112), (312), (200), (130) miller indices respectively. All the diffracted peaks were matched with JCPDS file 70-2113 and revealed that the designed catalyst exhibits monoclinic crystal of Ba2SiO4. No other peaks have been found in XRD pattern, which approves the single phase Ba2SiO4 formed without any impurity [26,29–31]. The most intense peak at 29.72° was taken to calculate the crystallite size of barium silicate by using Debye Scherrer equation. The size of crystal was determined and the obtained value is 74.32 nm by using Debye Scherrer equation. (2) D = 0.9 λ / β cos θ Here D is the average crystalline size, λ is the wave length ATR-FTIR FT-IR spectroscopy is one of the best techniques for analysis of surface functional groups present in synthesized catalyst. It was applied to investigate the functional group present in barium silicate (Ba2SiO4) synthesized via solid state method and shown in Fig. 3 . The stretching vibration band of Si-O and O–Si–O bond were observed at 1020 cm−1and 894 cm−1, respectively. While the absorption band at 510 cm−1, 733 cm−1and 1430 cm−1are referred to Si-O bending, Si-O-Si bending and Si=O stretching vibration respectively [32–34]. The band at the region 500–580 cm−1 is due to the Ba–O stretching vibrations. In addition, the last band at 603 cm−1 is attributed to the bridging oxygen of Si-O-Si bond [12,25]. All these spectra indicate that Ba2SiO4 formation which was confirmed by XRD pattern is in good agreement with FT-IR result. The FT-IR data mainly Si-O bending, Si-O-Si bending and Si=O stretching vibration obtained for Ba2SiO4 catalyst is also in agreement with our previous published result of Sr2SiO4 catalyst [12]. Surface area, basicity and turnover frequency N2 sorption isotherm study was carried out to determine the specific surface area of the Ba2SiO4 catalyst, and the results are shown in Fig. 4 . The specific surface area of synthesized Ba2SiO4 was found to be 19.07 m2/g and the pore diameter was 0.58 nm. The N2 physisorption of barium silicate exhibits type IV hysteresis loop and mesoporous characteristics. As the high surface area of a heterogeneous catalyst accelerates the transesterification reaction, the synthesised catalyst having a significant surface area facilitates the FAME conversion [35]. Similarly, the basic strength and total basicity of the synthesized catalyst was calculated by Hammett benzene carboxylic acid titration method with use few indicators (bromothymol blue) pKBH+ = 7.2, phenolphthaleine pKBH+ = 9.3, Nile blue pKBH+ = 10, 2,4-dinitroaniline pKBH+ = 15 and 4-nitroaniline KBH+ = 18) [12,28]. In presence of the catalyst, these indicators change their colour into respective basic form. The titration result showed that basic strength of synthesized catalyst was exist in range of 18.4 ˂ H−˃7.2. Table 1 show that total basicity of Ba2SiO4 was 10.6 mmol/g after increasing basicity at five different pKa levels. The catalyst Ba2SiO4 is more basic than our previous synthesized catalysts Sr2SiO4 (2.8 mmol/g) [12] and Ba2TiO4 (2.75 mmol/g) [28]. The lewis basic character of alkaline BaO contributes to the high basicity of the current catalyst, whereas transition metal oxides were responsible for the lewis basic nature of previously synthesised catalysts. The basicity test results demonstrate how well Ba2SiO4 functions as a base catalyst. The Lewis basic sites (Ba-O bond) in Ba2SiO4 can be anticipated to behave as the active site for base-catalysed transesterification [12,36,37]. SEM-EDX High resolution scanning electron microscopy (HR-SEM) study was conducted to find the morphology and structure of synthesized Ba2SiO4catalyst. HR-SEM micrograph and EDX spectra of the Ba2SiO4 samples calcined at 900 °C was depicted in Fig. 5 . It is observed that small pieces of barium silicate fused together to form a vermicular structure. Such type of structure was observed because of sintering of silica particle during calcination Most of the particles aggregated and exhibits flat vermicelli like structure with a mean diameter of 400–500 nm and 0.5–1 µm in length. When particles of Ba2SiO4 are close together, sintering occurs due to diffusion of anion and cation through specific routes. Therefore, sintering of the particles have been seen only in the contact points, as a result vermicular micro-structure was observed [38]. The appropriate Energy-dispersive X-ray spectroscopy (EDX) spectra were obtained from the catalyst's surface in order to ascertain the elemental composition of the Ba2SiO4 catalyst. The elements like Oxygen, silicon and barium are present in appropriate atomic weight percentage i.e. 44.86, 21.30, and 33.83, respectively. Analysis of biodiesel Biodiesel produced by transesterification of algal oil was analysed by 1H NMR spectroscopy using CDCl3 as solvent and recorded in 600 MHz Bruker spectrometer. The conversion percentage of FAME was calculated by using the equation (3) C Mester ( % ) = 2 × X 3 × Y × 100 Where X is the integration value of methoxy protons (-OCH3) at 3.6 ppm and Y is the integration value of α- methylene (-CH2-) protons at 2.3 ppm. Fatty methyl esters profile of synthesized biodiesel has been analysed by GC-FID. The composition of biodiesel suggests its suitability for fuel. Identified peaks were matched with NIST data base and related component shown in Table 2 . Methyl ester composition in biodiesel were C14:0 (2.20 %), C16:0 (53.58 %), C16:1 (1.7 %), C18:0 (6.67 %), C18:1 (9.37 %), C18:2 (24.45 %), C20:0 (0.21 %), C20:0 (0.47 %), C20:1 (0.47 %), C20:2 (0.12 %) and C24:0 (0.54 %) at retention time of 5.307, 7.898, 8.023, 10.624, 10.845, 11.369, 13.434, 13.589, 14.176, 16.159 and 19.429, respectively According to ASTM guidelines, the physico-chemical characteristics of synthesized FAME were evaluated, and the results were compared to those of the biodiesel standards listed in Table 3 . The physico-chemical properties such as calorific value, flash point, fire point and cetane number are close to our previously published data i.e, FAME derived from micro algal (Spirulina platensis) oil [12]. The catalyst's reusability was investigated using the hot methanol filtration method, which is significant from an economic standpoint. In order to get rid of any undesired contaminants and other organic material, the recovered catalyst was cleaned with hot methyl alcohol. It was then dried in an oven at 120 °C for 4 to 5 h before being used once more for subsequent cycles. Effect of reaction parameters on biodiesel yield The effect of a number of reaction parameters, including temperature, time, catalyst concentration, and oil to methanol molar ratio were investigated in the transesterification process and shown in Fig. 6 . The effect of the catalyst percentage on the conversion of biodiesel was investigated by increasing the catalyst loading percentage from 1 to 6 wt.% at other constant reaction parameters, such as 12:1 methanol to oil molar ratio, 400 rpm, and 65 °C for 4 h (Fig. 6a). Reduced catalyst loading was shown to produce inferior conversion because there were less accessible basic sites for the transesterification process. Biodiesel conversion increased to its highest level of 98.4 % when the loading percentage reached 4 wt% because an increase in active sites at higher catalyst concentrations enhances the transesterification reaction. The conversion of biodiesel was not improved by additional catalyst loading, and it began to inhibit the production of FAME. Such a shift in the synthesis of FAME may have resulted from a greater catalyst concentration and reduced reaction mixture dispersion [24,25]. The formation of a three-phasic system hindered the conversion of FAME because it made the reaction mixture more viscous due to emulsion formation with a larger catalyst loading and prevented mass transfer between reactants [13,39–41]. In our published work it is also observed that increased catalyst loading by 0.5 % also decreases FAME production due emulsion formation and increased rate of saponification [7,28]. The impact of molar proportion of alcohol and oil on yield of transesterification of Anabaena oil was studied and depicted in Fig. 6(b). Transesterification of Anabaena oil was carried out with regular interval of 1:2 to 1:16 molar proportion of oil to methanol keeping other parameters constant which is 4 % catalyst loading at 65 °C, 400 rpm for 4 h. It is observed that with increase in molar ratio of methanol the conversion percentage of biodiesel increased. It was achieved highest conversion of 98.4 % at 12:1 methanol to oil which might be due to formation of methoxy species on catalyst surface, that facilitate the reaction to move forward. Above 12:1 molar ratio of methanol to oil there was no increase in FAME synthesis due to dissolution of excess methanol in glycerol, which decrease the rate of reaction and favours backward reaction [7,28,42,43]. In our previous published study it is also demonstrated that the preparation of biodiesel from another species of algal (Spirulina platensis) oil employing β-Sr2SiO4 catalyst (2.5 %), resulting in 97.88 % FAME conversion at a 12:1 methanol to oil molar ratio [7,12]. In the previous study it is also observed that as methanol to oil molar ratio increases, FAME conversion decreases, which is in agreement with the current study. The effect of reaction time on methanolysis of Anabaena oil was also studied with varying reaction time from 30 min to 6 h (360 min) and depicted in Fig. 6(c). The other reaction parameters are 4 % catalyst loading, 12:1 molar ratio at 65 °C and 400 rpm. The conversion of biodiesel was increased gradually as time rises from 30 min to 4 h (240 min) and achieved highest conversion of Anabaena oil about 98.4 %. After 4 h, FAME conversion is not increasing significantly with increasing time which is in agreement with our published result [7,12]. The reaction process reaches equilibrium in 4 h, which is the optimum time to get highest conversion of Anabaena oil. Similarly, temperature shows a important role in accelerating the transesterification of Anabaena oil. The reaction was carried out at varied temperature from 35 to 80 °C at 4 % catalyst loading, 12:1 molar ratio, 400 rpm and is represented in Fig. 6(d). It is noticed that with rise in temperature from 35° to 65 °C there increase in conversion of FAME and attained highest conversion of 98.4 % at 65 °C, which is comparable to our previous obtained result of FAME synthesis from another species of algal oil [7,12,28]. Such type of increase in FAME synthesis might be due to increase in reaction rate since temperature acts as driving force to accelerate the reaction rate. As kinetic performance suggests high temperature enhances molecular collision and decreases the activation energy of reaction, so rate of reaction increases. But, above 65 °C, FAME conversion is reduced due to evaporation of alcohol and lack of availability of methanol in the reaction mixture [44,45]. Catalyst reusability study The cost of production determines the availability of biodiesel on a commercial scale. Making biodiesel can be less expensive if stable and reusable catalysts are used. From the perspective of green chemistry, it is also one of the key elements. The FAME conversion gradually reduced from 98.14 % to 77.64 % at the end of sixth cycle as shown in Fig. 7 . After sixth cycle the catalyst was regenerated by cleaning with hot methanol and calcined at 600 °C for 4 h. This regenerated catalyst was examined further at seventh cycle and obtained 94.89 % FAME conversion. The decrease in catalytic activity from first to sixth cycle probably due to leaching or blockage of the pores of synthesized catalyst with product or reactant molecules. Similar to Ca, K, and other elements, Si and Ba tend to leach into the solution more quickly. The catalyst leaching into the reaction mixture was investigated using the hot filtering method, and it was determined that Si leaching may be one of the causes of catalyst deactivation [46,47]. The regular, gradual loss of catalyst during the washing and heating operations is another factor that can be to responsible for the drop in catalytic activity. Kinetic studies Kinetics of the biodiesel synthesis process was studied to comprehend how reaction time and temperature impact the transesterification reaction. The order of the reactions was changed using regression analysis in order to identify the best model that will appropriately depict the transesterification process. A large amount of methanol is needed to change the reaction's direction toward ester production because it is a reversible process. Therefore, by ignoring the reverse reaction, the rate constant can be independent of the methanol concentration. Zero order was assumed in order to test this theory, and the equation that results does so is given below. (4) ln k = ln A − E a R T Here Ea = activation energy (kJ/mol), R= Gas constant (8.314 Jmol−1 K−1), K= rate constant in hr−1, A = frequency factor and T = temperature When graph is plotted against ln k vs. 1/T, ln A = intercept and E a R T =slope were obtained, which is depicted in Fig. 8 . The experimental data show good agreement with the first order model according to Eq. (4). The values of the correlation coefficients R2 given in Table 4 suggested a superior fit for the Anabaena oil transesterification reaction to the zero order model. The result shows that as reaction temperature rises, the rate constant does as well, encouraging molecular collisions by lowering the mass transfer restriction [48–50]. For pseudo-first order and zero order models, the computed activation energies were 36.428 and 19.463 kJ/mol, respectively. The overall kinetics analysis of the transesterification of Anabaena oil revealed that the reaction may be carried out under typical conditions of pressure and temperature. The reaction equilibrium constants were also studied in the temperature range of 45°–65 °C and the standard thermodynamic properties like ΔH# = 98.73 kJ mol−1, ΔG# = 23.53 kJ mol−1, ΔS# = 0.864 kJ mol−1 were obtained at 65 °C. Conclusion The major goal of this work is to investigate the catalytic effects of barium silicate, a less expensive and environmentally friendly alternative, on the transesterification of anabaena microalgae-derived algal oil. In the current study, the simplest solid-state technique was used to create a barium silicate (Ba2SiO4) base heterogeneous catalyst. The following methods such as TGA-DSC, XRD, ATR FT-IR, HRSEM-EDX, and BET-BJH method were used to examine the physical and chemical characteristics of the developed spinel catalyst. Anabaena pcc 7120 can be grown in a closed photobioreactor and produced a lot of biomasses as a result. Anabaena oil displayed the necessary lipid profile and acid value for the generation of biodiesel. Ba2SiO4 that was synthesised was approved as an effective catalyst for the production of biodiesel and about 98.4 % FAME conversion was obtained under ideal reaction conditions. The reaction parameters like molar ratio, catalyst loading and reaction time etc were optimized by OVAT techniques. The maximum 98.4 % conversion was obtained at 1:12 molar proportion of oil to methanol, 4.0 wt.% catalyst and 65 °C in 4 h. Ba2SiO4 showed 77.64 % conversions up to six rounds of reusability analysis under optimal reaction conditions. The fuel properties of the Anabaena oil methyl ester complied with ASTM D6751 standards. Thus, it was found that Ba2SiO4 was the best option for a heterogeneous catalyst in the commercial production of biodiesel. The kinetics and thermodynamics study suggested that reaction can be assed in normal condition of temperature and pressure. The positive value in standard Gibbs free energy also confirms that the entire reaction process is non-spontaneous and requires outer external energy for FAME conversion from algal oil. coredata.dc:description: The current work demonstrates a simple solid-state method for producing barium silicate catalyst for transesterification of Anabaena oil. The designed Ba2SiO4 spinel catalyst was characterised by following techniques such as thermo gravimetric analysis (TGA-DSC), powder X ray diffraction (P-XRD), furrier transfer infrared spectroscopy (FT-IR), scanning electron microscopy and electron diffraction spectroscopy (SEM-EDX), BET-surface area analyser and Hammett indictor acid-base titration method. The optimum condition for achieving highest FAME conversion of 98.4 % was observed at 65 °C, 12:1 methanol to oil molar ratio at 4h of reaction time. The catalyst was also stable up to six cycles with 98.1 % FAME conversion. Fuel properties of synthesized biodiesel were also compared with the ASTM standard. Kinetics studies revealed that transesterification of Anabaena oil is compactable with pseudo first order model with comparable activation energy 36.48 kJ/mol. The reaction equilibrium constants were also studied in the temperature range of 45°–65 °C and the standard thermodynamic properties like ΔH# = 98.73 kJ mol−1, ΔG# = 23.53 kJ mol−1, ΔS# = 0.864 kJ mol−1 were obtained at 65 °C.
coredata.dc:title: Synthesis of environmental benign biodiesel from algal (Anabaena) oil using Ba2SiO4 as efficient green catalyst
